comments.commentBody:
After yesterday's failure to gain any traction, was not hopeful about this. Started in the SW and moved clockwise until all I had left was "Persian language unit?" Stared at that for five minutes before the lightbulb finally went off.

Liked this puzzle because it fell to the work of slowly building each part. Though it's true I wouldn't have had a chance without knowing SATIE, NOLDE and KLEIN.

Thanks for the explanation, JFC; we've long known that I have not mastered thinking as you think.

I had it easy when I posted DON Everly b/c no one asked about connections to the puzzle. I had about 5 in mind (because they had so many songs and the lyrics are so memorable); but one of the clues that day was "Up", so my intro -- addressed to Suzie -- mentioned that clue. Too facile, I know.

I actually had another avatar picked out but when I learned that DON was Chicago-born and Fill was Kentucky-born that avatar was out of mind.

I tried to go back and read your "slew" of comments from late yesterday, MTF, but I couldn't get to the full scroll+replies without going through the whole song and dance of closing everything, opening the browser again, going to the Crosswords page, thence to Wordplay, playing arond to try to find that banner where you're allowed to open a column from a previous day, and then finally that day's comments. Maybe. I got bored and gave up. I'm sure your comments (and those of other late posters) were wonderful though.

Agree about Gail Collins's Saturday column.
Told you it's a tough room. But I thought your 'O2 be in England'  was very effervescent.

Notes on the Comment section for the FRI XWP blog:

1. Left a slew of late comments, including specific description of my problems and what software I am using, etc. I said there that some keys did not work, like ! and ( and ) and ' and ". Well they work on this page. I logged out and logged in before going to the SAT blog.
2. ELKE was heard from! Late comment. I tear up every time I see their alias, I always know she will have something delightful to say.
3. Why did so many people appear to be prevealing for William Peterson, when the avatar was the other guy?
4. I have a theory about why comments on this page might be more problematic than comments on, say, an Op-Ed column.
5. Gail Collins's Saturday column? Priceless. You will cry laughing.
6. When I wrote that I found one of Leapy's puns "shocking", you could never have understood me if the comments were out of order -- which is guaranteed. Leapy had typed something about ANANA Fill X-AXIS or some such, which put me into shock. Anaphylaxis? Shock? Wow, tough room.

-- Missing Those Fivethirtyamcomments
It is amazing that even in the firing and subsequent fallout it appears the cristy team is using their public power for petty vendetta.

Quite interesting to read the full letter of David Wildstein's attorney to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The Port Authority appears to be paying for the attorney representing Bill Baroni, Mr. Wildstein's boss at the Port Authority and a fellow Christie appointee, but is withholding such support from Mr. Wildstein.

Assuming that Mr. Wildstein is indeed cut loose by the Port Authority, wait for additional revelations.

The mayor of Fort Lee was on the phone immediately. The whole town was tied up, children couldn't get to school, ambulances were stuck etc. I believe he called the Port Authority, which manages the bridge and all the tunnels and the 3 airports -
2 in NYC and 1 in NJ. No way this flew "under the radar" nor that no one thought to complain. It was finally a NY state appointee to the Port Authority who got the lanes reopened, after 3 days.

Not true sir. It has been reported repeatedly there was a doctor who was so outraged he called everyone, including the governors office. I thought it was great! Finally someone with an ounce of intelligence not to just sit there and do nothing. I think the guy should run for Governor. I personally would've run the cones over and opened the lanes. It's the exact same mentality of airplane passengers who sit on runways for hours on end and do nothing. That's why they continually do it to the passengers.

" I find it a bit incredulous that no one called the governors office the moment those lanes were discovered shut down. "

So do I. In fact, it's impossibly, incredibly incredulous. What the governor knew and when he knew it (thank you, Howard Baker) ain't what he's telling us.

I find it a bit incredulous that no one called the governors office the moment those lanes were discovered shut down.

Out of all those commuters, not one wanted to know what was going on? And is anyone telling us that David Wildstein, a port authority just did this for a whim. Someone ordered this action, and it should not be hard to find out who, once the screws are turned tight enough. What whomever is responsible, did not seem to realize he/she was committing a federal offense that could get them a vacation in Club Fed.

Well a little poke in the right place, they will sing louder than Renee Fleming will Sunday.

As an aside, notice the snarkey comment about her singing by some French rapper, and some Fox news sport reporter, which shows the cultural low of too many people these days. So that may explain the defense of Christie that some poster have made.

This piece is a balanced, if sobering, assessment of the latest economic growth report. While the economy is slowly healing, progress has been uneven and the process has been far too slow. More than five years after the financial meltdown, America and the world still await a return to robust economic health. As well, economic gains have been concentrated among the richest and unemployment-- especially when data on labor force participation and discouraged workers are included-- remains far too high.

Europe's experience demonstrates compellingly that austerity does not produce growth. The U.S. experience shows that monetary policy is not sufficient to produce substantial economic growth in the face of restrained fiscal policy. In the face of this empirical evidence, it would be reasonable for governments in the U.S. and elsewhere to undertake more robust investment in job creation infrastructure, education, scientific research.

Unfortunately, dogma and paralyzing fears of inflation have prevented the use of fiscal policy to generate much-needed investment and demand. Even more callous is the cutting of U.S. jobless benefits to over a million citizens among the long-term unemployed.

Maybe Christie will enjoy being distracted for a few hours of gridiron mayhem on Sunday.
He might as well get used to a different life, having completely messed up his local political future to say nothing of his national ambitions.
He didn't know that Fort Lee was suffering from total gridlock as the school year started? It's not as though the busiest bridge in the world run by the Port Authority to which he had installed some big cronies would exactly be off his radar.
As the lid comes off and the bloom is off his rose even a basic function like distributing funds for Hurricane Sandy relief is mired in inefficiency and shenanigans, like using some of the funds to build housing for the elderly (good) in a town well outside the affected area (bad). And then there's Hoboken and pressure on the mayor to allow a particular developer free rein or else no more Sandy aid. Etc etc etc.

Who will the national Republican party find to be a reasonable presidential candidate for 2016? Their ranks are thin. That will last longer than the Super Bowl.
If only women had never gotten the vote.  The republican party wouldn't be headed for extinction.
When I glanced at the headline of this article, I read it as: "The Republican Party is in danger of becoming a man cave of madmen." Same difference, eh?

Given that Wildstein and Kelly were "highly experienced political operatives" they also knew that any of their political shenanigans would be denied by the boss and they would be fired.  This is a conversation that must go on in any campaign office.   Isn't it a chapter in the textbook for Politics 101?  Ms. Kelly knew this so well she brought boxes to her office the day Bridgegate became public.  Both operatives know that keeping quiet now will open up job opportunities for them in the future.  Mr. Wildstein, however, needs the Port Authority to pay his legal fees; money trumped loyalty.  Mr. Christie must have lost his influence with Port Authority officials or they surely would have paid Mr. Wildstein's legal fees so the bird wouldn't sing.

I agree with you totally. If, and just in case, that he did not know about the lane closure, he certainly should have known about it on the second day and investigated it! Besides, all along I wondered, why one would have to close all three lines for a traffic study and that for three or four days?

Janet, very good analysis. However, I think it is and always has been General Samson making the NJ PA decisions. Denying legal fee reimbursement was really stupid, especially when it pays for Baroni and one of the General's several defense firms. Of course, whether the PA pays or not, it would have no control over what Zegas and his client decide to do.

I hope that David Wildstein will be granted immunity by the U.S. Attorney in exchange for his testimony on the Fort Lee lane closings. The citizens of New Jersey deserve the truth.

My own sentiment is that it is unlikely that Bridget Anne Kelly and David Wildstein concocted the lane closings without the approval of Governor Christie or someone who they believed spoke for Christie. Both Kelly and Wildstein were highly experienced political operatives who knew that their jobs were to burnish the Governor's reputation, not to create problems for him out of the whole cloth. It strains credulity that Kelly and Wildstein would have gone rogue on this matter.

from the website:

"The health coverage costs below are subject to change based on detailed household information. Select "Apply" on a plan to begin the health care coverage application process."

Robert Weiler is woefully uninformed and simply making stuff up.

"Yon Cassius has a lean and hungry look, he thinks too much, such men are dangerous"

Howie

The mayor of Fort Lee was on the phone immediately. The whole town was tied up, children couldn't get to school, ambulances were stuck etc. I believe he called the Port Authority, which manages the bridge and all the tunnels and the 3 airports -
2 in NYC and 1 in NJ. No way this flew "under the radar" nor that no one thought to complain. It was finally a NY state appointee to the Port Authority who got the lanes reopened, after 3 days.

This is pricisely what's so laughable when they claim what a brilliant politician he is. Nothing could be farther from the truth. Had he kept his mouth shut and done his research he could've easily avoided the intensity of all of this. Granted what they did was in fact intentional but that is NOT what created this massive gridlock!

The bridge was built long before Fort Lee politicians destroyed the population. There are over 40,000 residents in a town not even 2.5 square miles when you factor in the highways. The population is so bad - every 4 days someone is either hit and or killed by a car, for the past three years. Over 220 people have been hit and over 25 are dead. Who's fault is that Mayor Sokolich?

This was not, I repeat, this was NOT a one time incident. Gridlock occurs every time the bridge backs up. For the Mayor of Fort Lee (Mark Jokolich as he is known to all the residents) to feign such indignation regarding endangering the lives of Fort Lee residents is just as laughable as Christie claiming he didn't know.

The Mayor is well aware of the life threatening situation in Fort Lee and went ahead and built two 47 story towers that will house an additional 900 rental units. Do the math. How many more residents and lives will be put at risk. Will Mayor Jokolich blame Christie for that as well? Yes what Christie did may've been intentional but what Mayor Jokolich did was far worse because he endangers the lives of the residents every day.
No, that would be Obamacare.

An able politician would not have joked in December that of course he knew about the closing; in fact he was the guy on the GWB moving the cones. He really seemed to think he was invincible.  I am not ashamed to admit that I have a major case of Schaudenfreude.

A more able politician would have thought of the ripple of consequences before viciously mocking and humiliating Mr. Wildstein in public as Gov Christie did at the news conference.

What also stands out about that incident is that Gov Christie is a former prosecutor. He knows the value of a pre-emptive strike to blatantly damage the credibility of someone who might be a key witness.

What can be counted on is Gov Christie won't resign unless forced to by law. He certainly doesn't want to defend himself with the only resources of an ordinary citizen. That means Gov Christie will be the gift that keeps giving to the media through the slow spots during 2014 election news.

Interestingly , George H.W. Bush son of a patrician politician lied about his age so he could enlist to fight in WW II. He was a war hero. He returned home and left his home state of Conneticut where life would have been easy and intead went to Texas. Like him or not to say he flourished is an understatement. He has never acted like anything other than a gentleman as you describe. Yet he was the subject of ridicule and scorn and referred to as a " wimp"  by literally the entire conservative movement including his son. That tells you all you need to know about the Republicans.

A real tough guy is also a gentleman, someone who is patient, polite, and shows self-restraint.  Only a weakling feels he has to prove what a real guy's guy he is, but a true gentleman knows better than that.  Maybe the Republicans can hire one--George H.W. Bush comes to mind--to teach themselves that lesson.
^ Key word is "thinking."
Good Lord, rigid gender stereotypes are wearing and offensive.  Why a thinking person would vote for a candidate who would espouse or play to such views is beyond me.  Enough, already.

When their "review" started, it was obvious that "approving" it was inevitable. They went through the motions of "deciding" because there is so much opposition. They're betting that the passion to oppose this has died down during the "review process." Time will tell if they got away with it or not.

Excellent comment about the growing marginalization of Americans in need.  This trend has grown increasingly nasty in recent years, and is reminiscent of attitudes in the latter part of the 19th century.

Piketty gets the diagnosis right but I wonder why he does not speak the solutions as expressed by THE watershed work on political economics written in 1879 entitled Progress and Poverty, Why there are recessions and poverty amid plenty - and what to do about it by Henry George. Download the free audio book by Bob Drake. The solution is not really so complicated or radical as much as it surprisingly simple. Instead of incentivising consumption, waste and monopolization a proper tax system recognizes conservation and thrift as the top economic virtues they rightly are. To this end labor is exactly the thing to be totally tax free. Labor stored up as capital should also have zero tax as well as the products of labor and capital such as infrastructure and development. Taxes on labor and production undermine natural incentives. Instead all public revenue must come from that which rightly and justly belongs to all, the earth and its riches. A "footprint tax" from each according to the tax each places on the balance of nature is what should support the public sector. This is a simple tax on the location of property and the minerals extracted according to the market value of each. Monopolization of mutual resources for tax free private gain is economically unjust and is a driver of unsustainable growth, criminal waste and our addictions to consumerism and greed. On top of all that, what could possibly nurture world wide political stability and security more than economic justice?

"Christie ... has the girth of a Falstaff, but sadly none of the charm!" ... That's why I call him "Corpus" Christie.

With any luck he'll soon be a political corpus as well as an anatomical one.

Another aspect of this, I guess of the moral hazard issue, is the extent to which we have not only been led into war by baby boomers who didn't serve in Vietnam, but the extent which many of those people, perhaps not wanting to look like "sissies," or maybe guild-ridden, support military budgets and policies even when we haven't started a war. Like they are afraid to say no to the military. Think Clinton.

I sometimes wonder what it would have been like if, say, Al Gore (who did serve in the military) had been elected instead of Bush. Aside from the fact that it is extremely unlikely he would have started the war in Iraq, I wonder whether he would have been less willing to say yes to all the Defense Dept. excesses of the past several decades.

Follow the benefit.

Sure wasn't the people on the George Washington Bridge, or those living/driving anywhere near it.

'... in a recent court filing in a concussion lawsuit, the N.C.A.A.’s lawyers wrote that “the N.C.A.A. denies that it has a legal duty to protect student-athletes.”'

Yeah, time to unionize.
She gets hysterical without any sign of trouble also.

Thomas Zaslavsky is right to castigate Ann Coulter for mania or silliness. "Hysterical", alas, comes from a very sexist Greek origin, since "hysterix" means "womb" or "uterus"! Yes, the Greeks whom we love and admire as proto-democratic had a sexist understanding of emotions. A while back, when I was in school, a long while back, so, I admit, we were socialized to regard showing or feeling emotion as unmasculine.I'd say "Ann Coulter shows irrationality and petty rages", not that she is "hysterical". Christie and Rob Ford of Toronto seem irrational and rage-filled, and have no uteri.

When Ann Coulter says "women ... always become hysterical at the first sign of trouble", isn't it obvious that she means herself?

Not that she realizes it. Not at all.
MTF, Because Petersen was in the Puzzle and he was the connection.  The other guy made it more difficult because it was Friday.
Good to have you back, pm.
It's grand to have a commenter returning rather than leaving the blog! Welcome back paulymath.

Great 2CU back pm, in the am, or at anytime of the day, for that matter!

Howie

So, after another brief hiatus I decided to jump back in again with both feet on a Saturday. Lucky me. This one was imaginative, fun, and, mirabile dictu, a breeze! I literally cannot remember the last Saturday puzzle I solved unassisted. If this is how it's gonna be, I might become a regular solver again—not that my drifting away from the XWPs three or four months back was because of their difficulty.

Process matters!  Science works because its results are repeatable.  If economics purports to be a science-- rather than sociology/psychology with calculus stapled onto is behind, to impress/scare off the math-o-phobes-- it needs to have explanatory theory backed up by repeatable results.  Otherwise you'd never be abler to serve your pudding to guests, for fear that it would poison them.  bc
